column4: I am having trouble shutting down ubuntu. I get as far as the ubuntu screen and the line going the opposite direction it does at startup. Then the screen goes black and theres a blinking white - up in the left hand corner. There it stays. I've wa
ed around five minutes and still nothing
does it turn off  on it's own like it's meant to or not?
does the computer still turn off on it's own?
No. I have to hold down the power button to get it to shut down.

I see,   well  not sure what's causing it, but   what I do know is, that you can  hold down your power button and turn off  a  Linux distro,  without it  complaining at you the next time you turn it on again, like Windows would
basically  you  don't have to  shut down  like  you would Windows,  just use the power button if you like
I remember reading somewhere it was bad for your comptuer to do that
I  think if you  switch it off via the plug then, yes possibily
,but  via the power button  it should be alright,  plus then the hardware knows, it's going to turn off?
Mmkay.
your issue will probably disappper in Karmic,  which isn't released as a final yet.   also  HAL is being replaced in that one
I am actually running karmic currently. jaunty wouldn't recogonize my wireless/ethernet
ah ha I see
same here,   I think  I  had  a similar issue before,  or was that the vm,   by the way  for Karmic help you should be using #ubuntu+1 really
this psyicail install seems to be shutting down fine, but the vm I had before this was a bit hmm
oh. I didn't know there was a karmic help irc.
I went to ubuntu+1.. there isn't anyone responding
just wait
I'll try. <_<
yes
How would I go about doing that?
altough a waste of a DVD really space wise, since the ISO is really for a CD
download  the ISO, and check the ISO before downloading that's a good idea
uh before burning I meant
and make sure your burning the contents of the ISO, rather than the ISO itself
Is there a certain program I should use?
I assume your on Windows right now?
Vista. Yes.
imgburn is good and will do it,  but most proper burning softwares, can do  this these days
is that a free program?
if not all the proper ones,   Nero etc,   and yes  Imgburn is free
as in price, not freedom, for imgburn
so I want to write and image file to a disk?
yes
and I suggested checking that your download is good before burning
how do if the download is good?
already  gave the bot thing to you, but won't hurt doing it again, but hmm someone beat me to that
here's my reply to what you told me in pm]
how much RAM?
oh it's you again
yup. Uh, it says 256mb. thats what it says in the bios
ok  that explains it  maybe
altough Ubuntu can boot on 256MB ARM
it's 128MB   where  you got to do something a little special
okay. hold on. brb.
when you get back see above, my messages to   trism
so what should i do?
see above my messages to trism
or the SWAP trick
You can get the Gparted Live CD and  put on your SWAP partition
I have no clue what that is.
or   use the alternate CD

you can  put  on a  512MB or so SWAP partition   on the hard disk with the Gparted CD,  and  hopefuly the desktop CD will  boot up properly, and that will probably be the case,   or do the alternate yeah
and you want to get rid of the Windows on there, and anything in it, right?
yup
so then for the alternative method, I do the same thing?
what same thing?  md5sum? yep
just  you get a differnet code
I mean burn to a disc.
yes
do you think this'll work?
it's worth a try
you also can do the SWAP trick
whats the swap trick?
where you put a 512MB or so SWAP partition on the hard disk using the Gparted Live CD,  and then try  and boot up  the Desktop CD again
well that works for 128MB RAM,   and  really yours should be booting up properly with 256MB RAM, but maybe it will help  with that as well.
did you md5sum the ISO for desktop though?
is there a different distro I could use?
there are two that are specifically made for older hardware
what are those?
,but try  alternate  first, and then if that don't work SWAP  trick,  and then   well  other distros sure
I'd have to install a torrent, which I'm not interested in doing.
Damn Small Linux  and there's Puppy Linux plus many versions of it,  Puppy  being the better of the two
mmkay. I'll check those out. do they have support forums like this?
I said to do those as option three
if opton one or two won't work, and Ubuntu has better support
Ubuntu has much better support
since a lot more users
what you mean install a torrent?  that's one way you can download   Linux ISO's  usaully though, torrents
and you can download the alternate CD without using a   torrent, same thing for the Gparted Live CD
that isn't an option on the alternative downloads page.
what page are you on?
http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/downloadmirrors#alternative
the alternateve or whatever, is going on the old desktop?  not  a netbook, right?
the gateway is a laptop
the mirrors at the bottom of the page seem to be for ISO's anyway   http://releases.ubuntu.com/9.04/   and you can download the ISO  as well as get the md5sum,  when you click on those links
Okay. Now we wait.
okay, so I did the alternative install and now I'm getting an acpi: invalid _PTC data message
no idea what that means, did you Google it?
actually, I waited it out.. and I think its installing
So, neither of the methods you suggested worked.
you did  the SWAP on gparted cd?
yup.
well  I  guess  you got hardware problems, after all the XP on there, won't even boot up
do you think I could fit puppy on there?
of course it's  tiny
I guess that's what I'll have to try. Thanks.
